author: By Kristen Bateman
title: Foundation Is Dead
description: Gone are the days of full-coverage foundation that conceals all of skin’s flaws. A new era is ushering in a wave of self-acceptance.
content: Donni Davy, the “Euphoria” makeup artist, doesn’t use foundation or powder on the cast. And when she introduced her own beauty line earlier this year, Half Magic, she chose to focus on eye shadows, lip liners and lipsticks, hybrid blush-highlighters and adhesive crystals — but no concealer or foundation. For the line’s ad campaign, she used minimal watered-down foundation for spot treatments, and she insisted that images show skin’s pores, texture and bumps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Elemia
title: What Martial Law? Marcoses Get Star Treatment in New Film.
description: A big-budget production depicts the family as victims of a political vendetta, a popular narrative during the recent presidential election in the Philippines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden and Eduardo Medina
title: Jury Acquits Truck Driver of All Charges in Crash That Left 7 Bikers Dead
description: Volodymyr Zhukovskyy, 26, was facing 15 charges after being accused of causing a collision that killed a group of motorcyclists on a rural road in Randolph, N.H.
content: A jury in New Hampshire on Tuesday acquitted a commercial truck driver of all charges in connection with a 2019 crash on a rural highway that killed seven members of a motorcycle club and shocked the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Reid J. Epstein
title: Five Takeaways From Tuesday’s Elections
description: In a series of primaries in Wisconsin and a handful of other states, the power of a Trump endorsement resonated.
content: The day after F.B.I. agents searched his home in Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump yet again illustrated his electoral pull on the Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Is There Any End to the Ukraine War in Sight?
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine wants the war to end by 2023. Is that wishful thinking?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 2022-23 Student Contest Calendar: Fall Semester
description: This year’s lineup mixes classic challenges with new opportunities. Stay tuned for our spring offerings, which we’ll add later this year.
content: Hundreds of thousands of students from around the world have participated in our contests over the 13 years we’ve been running them, creating podcasts, writing editorials, making videos, reviewing arts and culture, composing narratives, investigating scientific phenomena, and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump and James sat across from each other for hours as he said ‘same answer’ again and again.
description: A lawyer for Donald J. Trump said that over the course of about four hours, the former president answered only one question, about his name, toward the beginning of the interview.
content: The New York State attorney general, Letitia James, sat across from Donald J. Trump as he repeatedly declined to answer questions, invoking his right against self-incrimination during a deposition on Wednesday, according to one of Mr. Trump’s lawyers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
title: Hunting for Voter Fraud, Conspiracy Theorists Organize ‘Stakeouts’
description: A nascent effort to surveil drop boxes for potential fraud is taking shape in at least 10 states, worrying election officials and law enforcement.
content: One night last month, on the recommendation of a man known online as Captain K, a small group gathered in an Arizona parking lot and waited in folding chairs, hoping to catch the people they believed were trying to destroy American democracy by submitting fake early voting ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Review: An Opera’s Exquisite Brutality Arrives in America
description: George Benjamin and Martin Crimp’s “Lessons in Love and Violence” is a masterly follow-up to their acclaimed “Written on Skin.”
content: LENOX, Mass. — The problem with “Lessons in Love and Violence” has always been that it is not “Written on Skin.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Policing Divide Hurt Rep. Ilhan Omar, Who Edged Out a Narrow Primary Win
description: A progressive push for police accountability after the 2020 murder of George Floyd in Minnesota sparked a backlash that boosted Ms. Omar’s primary opponent.
content: Two years ago, Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota easily survived her Democratic primary by beating back a fellow progressive. Even though she had become a national lightning rod for attacks from the right and faced staunch opposition from pro-Israel groups that spent millions of dollars in hopes of defeating her, she won her 2020 race by more than 35,000 votes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Egner
title: In ‘House of the Dragon,’ Paddy Considine Claims the Crown
description: A string of critically acclaimed roles has made him many British actors’ favorite actor. It has also lifted him from hardscrabble roots to a seat on the Iron Throne.
content: WINSHILL, England — On a blindingly sunny June afternoon, Paddy Considine whipped his sedan through a working-class neighborhood in this suburb in the West Midlands, pointing out the stolid taverns, churches and council houses that combine to cast the long shadows of his childhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Prosecutors Face Distrust in Second Try to Prove Plot to Kidnap Michigan’s Governor
description: Two men are charged with conspiring to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. But a first trial ended with no convictions, and questions about the F.B.I.’s tactics.
content: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. — Four months after one of the most closely watched domestic terrorism trials in recent history ended with zero convictions, federal prosecutors are trying again to convince Michigan jurors that there was a plot in 2020 to kidnap Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, set off explosives and foment a civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The poor face a one-two punch: inflation now and job loss later.
description: Higher-income households built up savings and wealth during the early stages of the pandemic as they stayed at home and their stocks, houses and other assets rose in value, The New York Times’s Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman report. Between those stockpiles and solid wage growth, many have been able to keep spending even as costs climb.
content: Higher-income households built up savings and wealth during the early stages of the pandemic as they stayed at home and their stocks, houses and other assets rose in value, The New York Times’s Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman report. Between those stockpiles and solid wage growth, many have been able to keep spending even as costs climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Two Trump Scenarios
description: What should you make of the F.B.I.’s search of Donald Trump’s home? We offer a guide.
content: Perhaps the central question about the F.B.I.’s search of Donald Trump’s Florida home is whether it is a relatively narrow attempt to recover classified documents — or much more than that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Scatter Your Sushi
description: Try a no-recipe recipe for chirashi, or Kay Chun’s recipe for sesame salmon bowls.
content: Good morning. I love Kay Chun’s recipe for sesame salmon bowls (above), inspired by the sushi dish known as chirashi, which comes from the Japanese word for “scattered.” It’s fast and flavorful. You make a version of sushi rice, the grains cooked in water and vinegar, then steam salmon on top and serve it with a soy-sesame dressing and one of my favorite supermarket-ingredient short cuts: bagged, pre-cut coleslaw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason M. Bailey
title: Raymond Briggs, Who Drew a Wordless ‘Snowman,’ Dies at 88
description: An author and illustrator of children’s books sensitive to emotions, he used comic-strip-like panels to explore the joys and struggles of workaday British life.
content: Raymond Briggs, the children’s author whose cheeky illustrations dignified workaday British life and an audacious breadth of emotions, most prominently in the wordless escapades of “The Snowman,” died on Tuesday in Brighton, England. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Irina Aleksander
title: The Russian Filmmaker Trapped Between Hollywood and Moscow
description: As boycotts of Russia expand to include cultural exports, artists like Kirill Serebrennikov must prove they are dissident enough to enjoy a Western audience.
content: Last December, a few months before Russia invaded Ukraine, Kirill Serebrennikov, the film and theater director, applied for parole on the basis of good behavior. Serebrennikov was arrested in 2017 on embezzlement charges, though it was widely understood that his real offense was producing work that irritated the Kremlin. He spent 20 months on house arrest and another year standing trial, before being sentenced to three years’ probation. In late March, a Russian court suspended his remaining sentence, and the very next day, he fled to Germany. By May, he was at the Cannes Film Festival, in the south of France, for the premiere of his new film, “Tchaikovsky’s Wife.” When Serebrennikov emerged in a small room at the Palais des Festivals for a news conference, the moderator introduced him as “someone who we’ve eagerly awaited for three years.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaux Laskey
title: 24 Freezer-Friendly Recipes to Cook for New (and Tired) Parents
description: A collection of ready-to-eat meals is almost as good as a full night’s sleep.
content: Nothing can prepare someone for the level of exhaustion and elation that accompanies the early days of parenthood. But helping stock a friend’s freezer with delicious, nourishing dishes that need just a few minutes in the oven or microwave can certainly help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Sean Patrick Maloney Wins a Clinton Endorsement (Bill, Not Hillary)
description: The former president said he would vote for and endorse Mr. Maloney over a challenger from the left, State Senator Alessandra Biaggi.
content: Former President Bill Clinton waded into one of New York’s most contentious Democratic primaries on Wednesday, saying that he would cast his vote for Representative Sean Patrick Maloney in a newly redrawn suburban district that includes his Chappaqua home and “urge all my neighbors to do the same.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso
title: Peekskill, N.Y.: An ‘Artist’s Paradise’ on the Hudson River
description: Newcomers praise this diverse Westchester city for its galleries, art studios and welcoming vibe: ‘It’s easy to be part of the community.’
content: With its industrial roots and lively art scene, Peekskill — or “PK,” as some call it — is considered a “mini Beacon,” a reference to the art-centric city in upstate New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Trump’s Campaign-Style Video Sets Off 2024 Talk, but There’s a Back Story
description: The former president posted the video on his social media site hours after his Florida home was searched by the F.B.I., and at a time when he is widely seen as eyeing a third White House bid.
content: A campaign-style video that former President Donald J. Trump posted on his social media site this week has prompted fact-checks and a new round of speculation about whether he is on the verge of announcing a third bid for the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zengerle
title: Why Isn’t Biden Ever on TV?
description: Americans are seeing a lot less of the president than they did of his predecessor. That’s partly by design.
content: On a sweltering day last month, President Biden traveled to Somerset, Mass. Appearing on a bulldozed patch of land where a coal-fired power plant recently stood, and where a substation for an offshore wind farm eventually will, Biden delivered what the White House press office billed as remarks on “actions to tackle the climate crisis.” The previous week, Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia seemingly torpedoed Biden’s ambitious climate package (though Manchin would soon resurrect it). In the meantime, much of the country was suffering from extreme weather: wildfires, floods, record heat. Now Biden, sporting Ray-Bans and forgoing a tie in the blistering heat, looked out at the crowd and the cameras. “Let me be clear,” he declared. “Climate change is an emergency.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Classic Pumps Stage a Comeback
description: This season’s heels come in a range of heights and finishes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Hurtes and Julie Turkewitz
title: In the Amazon, a U.N. Agency Has a Green Mission, but Dirty Partners
description: One of the world’s largest sustainable development agencies has worked with energy companies to quash opposition and keep oil flowing, even in sensitive areas.
content: RESGUARDO BUENAVISTA, Colombia — At the edge of the Colombian Amazon, in an Indigenous village surrounded by oil rigs, the Siona people faced a dilemma.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Japanese Myths to African Fashion
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: THE JAPANESE MYTHS: A Guide to Gods, Heroes and Spirits, by Joshua Frydman. (Thames & Hudson, $24.95.) A professor of Japanese literature ushers readers through the country’s mythology from the earliest written stories to the rise of the manga industry and situates Japan’s rich cultural tradition within religious and historical developments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Can Trump take the Fifth in a civil case?
description: The constitutional amendment establishes protection against self-incrimination in criminal cases, but it can be invoked in other contexts.
content: The Fifth Amendment established a bedrock protection against self-incrimination — in criminal cases. It says that no person “shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Beluga Whale Dies in France During Last-Ditch Rescue Mission
description: The 13-foot, 1,800-pound animal had been removed from the Seine river where it had been stranded for days, but it was later euthanized after experiencing difficulty breathing.
content: PARIS — A malnourished beluga whale that had been stranded in the Seine river for several days, causing its health to deteriorate rapidly, died on Wednesday a few hours after being removed from the water in a last-ditch rescue operation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Who Won and Who Lost in Primary Elections in Wisconsin and Elsewhere
description: Republicans chose Tim Michels to challenge Gov. Tony Evers in Wisconsin, and Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes will take on Senator Ron Johnson. In Washington State, a House Republican who voted for impeachment conceded her race.
content: Four states held primary elections on Tuesday — and we got a concession in one of last week’s House races in Washington State. Here’s a rundown of some of the most important wins and losses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ava Sasani, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Miriam Jordan
title: Man Charged in Albuquerque Killings Had Been Accused of Beating Relatives
description: The police in Albuquerque revealed details of the evidence against Muhammad Syed, an Afghan immigrant who has been charged in the shooting deaths of two fellow Muslims.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — The Afghan man accused of killing two Muslim men in Albuquerque had been charged in a series of assaults in recent years, accused of beating his wife and son and attacking a man whom his daughter was dating, according to police records released on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: FIFA Seeks Last-Minute Change to World Cup Schedule
description: In a letter sent only months before the tournament, organizers have requested that the World Cup start one day earlier and allow Qatar, the host nation, to feature in its first match.
content: Qatar has had 12 years to plan for the World Cup. Now, with the first games of the tournament just over 100 days away and the intricate match schedule announced months ago, organizers have requested changes that would make the event start a day earlier so the host nation can have a featured place in the opening game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Is Coming. Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: HBO’s new “Game of Thrones” prequel takes us back to the land of Westeros, hundreds of years earlier. We’ve got your cheat sheet.
content: In the final episodes of HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” the mad queen Daenerys Targaryen incinerated most of the capital city of King’s Landing. But what was it like when it was all still standing, and the Targaryen dynasty ruled with an iron fist — er, throne?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: New York City Can Reinstate School Budget Cuts, Court Rules
description: With the first day of school in New York less than a month away, the city is caught up in a contentious legal battle over whether to cut school funding.
content: More than $200 million in cuts to the New York City public school budget are back in effect, at least temporarily, after a state appeals court on Tuesday put a hold on a lower court’s ruling requiring the city to redo the budget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Hungary Settles Russia’s Bill With Ukraine to Restore Oil Flows
description: Hungary’s energy conglomerate, MOL, paid Russia’s transit fees to Ukraine, ensuring that oil keeps flowing through an overland pipeline that remains crucial for Central Europe.
content: BERLIN — Hungary’s main oil conglomerate said on Wednesday that it would pay an outstanding bill owed by Russia’s oil pipeline operator to the Ukrainian authorities, clearing the way for Russian oil deliveries to resume to three Central European countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: Europe’s Energy Crisis May Get a Lot Worse
description: Do Americans understand the stakes across the Atlantic?
content: I don’t think many Americans appreciate just how tense and tenuous, how very touch and go the energy situation in Europe is right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: Yotam Ottolenghi Has Made Thousands of Meringues. This Is His Favorite.
description: There are many variations of the simple, elegant sweet — but pavlova with seasonal fruit is among the best.
content: My professional encounters with meringue happened to follow a trajectory that took me from very small to extra-large.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Quammen
title: We Are Still in a Race Against the Coronavirus
description: Human ingenuity must keep up with the coronavirus.
content: The Covid-19 pandemic has been a lesson in speed — the speed at which a novel virus among humans can spread, the speed at which it can rack up fatalities and cripple economies, the speed at which vaccines can be designed and produced, the speed at which misinformation can undermine public health. Amid all that rapidity is a different kind of speed, which drives the rest, like an engine spinning the cars on a nauseating carnival ride: the speed of viral evolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Can ‘House of the Dragon’ Be HBO’s Next ‘Game of Thrones’?
description: The stakes are high for the first “Thrones” spinoff, which could determine nothing less than the future of the franchise.
content: LOS ANGELES — George R.R. Martin has seen the comments, and he’s read the emails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: The Superbly Original, Gloriously Weird B-52’s Say Farewell to the Road
description: Forty-three years after their first album, the band that brought the world “Rock Lobster” and “Love Shack” is starting a tour for the last time.
content: When the B-52’s played “Rock Lobster” on “Saturday Night Live” in January 1980, a few months after releasing their debut album, it was a lightning-strike moment for a generation of young misfits and oddballs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ana Swanson
title: Inflation Cooled in July, Welcome News for White House and Fed
description: Prices have increased rapidly since last year, but barely budged in July — a positive development, though not yet enough for a victory lap.
content: Inflation cooled notably in July as gas prices and airfares fell, a welcome reprieve for consumers and a positive development for economic policymakers in Washington — though not yet a conclusive sign that price increases have turned a corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Greenest Block Grows in Brooklyn
description: A block of Lincoln Place in Crown Heights is the winner of an urban gardening award. Its trees lower temperatures, one of the gardeners says.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out why a block in Crown Heights is Brooklyn’s greenest. And, how much has inflation driven up food prices in New York? Scroll down for a sample of New York staples that cost more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Julia Lester on Her ‘More Knowing’ Little Red Riding Hood
description: Her bold choices for “Into the Woods” have garnered the 22-year-old actress critical acclaim and a Broadway debut.
content: Conventional wisdom has it that actors should not audition in costume. But Julia Lester did so anyway — fashioning a red cape out of a circle skirt — when she videotaped her audition for the part of Little Red Riding Hood in the Encores! production of “Into the Woods” this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Are Democrats Bungling Their Outreach to Voters?
description: Readers react to a guest essay critical of email fund-raising appeals with a desperate tone. Also: The raid at Mar-a-Lago; the Alex Jones case.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Kenyans on Tenterhooks as Votes Are Counted in Presidential Race
description: Conflicting estimates of which candidate was ahead suggested a very tight race. Official results are expected to take several days.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyans waited anxiously on Wednesday for the results of their presidential election, the most closely fought in years, amid conflicting estimates of which candidate was ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Astronomers May Have Found the Galaxy’s Youngest Planet
description: The Webb telescope soon will help measure the world, which may offer insights into how our own formed.
content: Over the last 30 years, astronomers have found more than 5,000 exoplanets, an eclectic menagerie of worlds far from our stellar neighborhood. The latest may be a mere infant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: A House Republican who voted to impeach Trump loses her race in Washington State.
description: Marie Perez, a Democrat, and Joe Kent, a Trump-backed Republican, will face off in November after winning their “jungle primary” against Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler, who criticized Trump after Jan. 6.
content: Representative Jaime Herrera Beutler of Washington, a Republican who voted to impeach former President Donald J. Trump and sharply criticized his actions leading up to the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, conceded her primary Tuesday in a crowded race that included a Trump-backed challenger and other 2020 election deniers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Brad Finstad wins a special election to fill the seat of Rep. Jim Hagedorn, who died in February.
description: Mr. Finstad, a Republican, will complete the final four months remaining in the term of Mr. Hagedorn, also a Republican.
content: Brad Finstad, a Republican former state lawmaker in Minnesota, won a special election for a U.S. House seat, according to The Associated Press. He will complete the final four months remaining in the term of Representative Jim Hagedorn, a Republican, who died from cancer in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Trump is baselessly suggesting that the F.B.I. may have planted evidence during its search.
description: In a post on his social media app, he suggested without evidence that federal agents may have planted incriminating materials before searching his residence in Florida on Monday.
content: Even as former President Donald J. Trump invoked the Fifth Amendment in a New York inquiry into his business practices, he and his allies began an effort to discredit another investigation, suggesting without evidence that federal agents may have planted incriminating materials before searching his residence in Florida on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawna Richer
title: Serena Williams Bids Farewell to Canadian Tennis Fans
description: Williams’s second-round match on Wednesday at the National Bank Open was her last in Canada, and everyone wanted in on it, even Wayne Gretzky.
content: TORONTO — Karl Hale has been the tournament director at the National Bank Open since 2006 and had never seen anything like the 24 hours after Serena Williams said she was winding down her professional tennis career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney Profit Jumps 50 Percent, and Streaming Subscribers Surpass Netflix
description: The company unveiled details of an ad-supported Disney+ as demand at its theme parks rebounded.
content: LOS ANGELES — Bucking a streaming slowdown that has recently bedeviled Hollywood, Disney+ added 14.4 million subscribers in the most recent quarter, about 45 percent more than Wall Street had expected and lifting Disney’s portfolio of streaming services to 221 million subscribers worldwide, edging ahead of Netflix for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Becca Balint wins a Vermont House primary, with the backing of Senator Bernie Sanders.
description: She is expected to prevail in November and become the first woman the state has sent to Congress.
content: Becca Balint, a progressive leader in the Vermont Legislature who had the support of the state’s most influential political figure, Senator Bernie Sanders, won the Democratic primary for the state’s lone seat in Congress, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Taxpayers for U.S. Chips
description: What a $280 billion law signed by President Biden this week might mean for Americans.
content: ​​The United States has authorized $280 billion in taxpayer money to subsidize rich computer chip companies and invest in technology research for the sake of keeping America strong and innovative.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Los Angeles Bans Encampments Near Schools
description: The City Council voted on Tuesday to prohibit homeless people from setting up tents within 500 feet of public and private schools and day care centers.
content: In a highly contested move, Los Angeles this week significantly expanded restrictions on where homeless people can sleep as the city, the nation’s second largest, grapples with its housing crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Ben Protess, Michael S. Schmidt, Luke Broadwater and William K. Rashbaum
title: F.B.I. Search of Trump’s Home Pushes Long Conflict Into Public View
description: Justice Department officials were worried that the former president had not fully complied with requests to return material taken from the White House that included possible classified information.
content: The search carried out on Monday by the F.B.I. at former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home, a law enforcement action with explosive legal and political implications, was the culmination of a lengthy conflict between a president proud of his disdain for rules and officials charged with protecting the nation’s records and secrets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: ‘Final’ Nuclear Deal on Table for Iran and U.S. to Weigh
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, August 10, 2022.
content: “This is their style: moving toward an agreement but at the moment of agreement saying, ‘There’s just one more thing.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Wisconsin Republicans Embrace Trump in a Race Defined by 2020 Grievances
description: Tim Michels, the former president’s choice in the primary for governor, beat an establishment-backed rival to set up a closely watched November race against Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat.
content: Republican primary voters upended their party’s establishment in Wisconsin on Tuesday, choosing a Trump-backed candidate for governor who has entertained overturning the 2020 election results to take on Gov. Tony Evers, a Democrat, in one of the country’s most consequential November contests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Jonah E. Bromwich and Benjamin Protess
title: What happens next in the New York attorney general’s inquiry?
description: Since former President Donald J. Trump declined to answer questions, Attorney General Letitia James faces a crucial decision.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s decision to invoke his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination leaves the New York attorney general, Letitia James, with a crucial decision: whether to sue Mr. Trump or to seek a settlement that could extract a significant financial penalty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: For Sale: The ‘Sexiest’ Hourly Rate Hotel in Manhattan
description: The owner calls the Liberty Inn “the cleanest short-stay hotel in town.” But in a changing neighborhood, “a hotel like this doesn’t make sense,” he says.
content: The Liberty Inn, the last hourly rate hotel in Manhattan’s meatpacking district, sits alone on a tiny triangular block beside the West Side Highway. Its website bills its rooms as the “most sexiest” in the city, and for nearly 50 years it has provided sanctuary for bouts of afternoon passion, clandestine affairs and lunchtime quickies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Jackson
title: What Does ‘Vex Money’ Do to Love?
description: We Black women and girls must protect ourselves. Still, I wish I could relax into the plush comfort of a relationship.
content: Vex money. Noun. Origin: Anglophone Caribbean. Meaning: money stashed on your person or in a secret place (a brassiere, a bank account, your grandmother’s Bible, your sneakers). To be spent only in case of emergency brought upon by a once stable situation suddenly becoming vexed — usually but not always because of a man. See: the need for a swift exit in response to the threat of sexual assault. See also: the dissolution of a relationship, the loss of a job or being displaced from your home. Related to but not the same as the threat often uttered by an Afro-Caribbean woman: “Don’t get me vex.” Or “She/he/they get me vex, get me on my nerves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Boston School Dean Recruited Students for Latin Kings, U.S. Says
description: Prosecutors said Shaun Harrison, 63, lived a “double life” as a leader of the drug gang while working at a public high school.
content: A former Boston public school official who recruited at-risk students into the Latin Kings gang and had the students distribute drugs on campus pleaded guilty to racketeering charges on Tuesday, the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the District of Massachusetts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Noah Weiland
title: For Older Americans, Health Bill Will Bring Savings and ‘Peace of Mind’
description: Starting in 2025, Medicare recipients with prescription drug coverage will not have to pay more than $2,000 annually for medications, a significant savings for some.
content: WASHINGTON — After Pete Spring was diagnosed with dementia in 2016, he and his wife emptied their checking account in part to pay for his prescription drugs, then ran through $60,000 in pension payments before resorting to a charge card to help make sure Mr. Spring had the heart and Alzheimer’s medications he needed to survive — just two of the 11 drugs he took.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Michael Crowley
title: Justice Dept. Charges Iranian in Plot to Kill John Bolton
description: Prosecutors said a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps sought the murder of the former national security adviser in retaliation for the killing of a top Iranian official.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department charged a member of Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps on Wednesday with planning to assassinate John R. Bolton, who served as the national security adviser to President Donald J. Trump, as payback for the killing of a senior Iranian official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airfares tumbled as jet fuel prices fell.
description: Fares fell nearly 8 percent in July from June, a drop that helped to bring down overall inflation.
content: Airline ticket prices fell sharply in July after peaking in recent months, fueled by high costs, high demand and a limited number of flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Sydney Harper, Stella Tan, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Rowan Niemisto, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood
title: The F.B.I. Search of Trump’s Home
description: What have we learned about the agency’s unprecedented decision to enter Mar-a-Lago?
content: On Monday, federal agents descended on Mar-a-Lago, the private club and Florida home of former President Donald J. Trump, reportedly looking for classified documents and presidential papers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Olbermann
title: The Greatest Athlete of All Time? Jim Thorpe.
description: In the new biography “Path Lit by Lightning,” David Maraniss details the enormous odds that a Native American hero had to overcome.
content: Forty summers ago, a man wearing a tracksuit stepped out onto Fifth Avenue to celebrate his 90th birthday by running down the sidewalk in front of the Guggenheim Museum. He was there to publicize the New York City Marathon because in those days the New York City Marathon still needed the help. But, as nearly always happened to Abel Kiviat, the talk quickly turned to Jim Thorpe because there is a convincing argument to be made that Thorpe was the greatest athlete of all time. And 70 years earlier, Abel Kiviat had been Jim Thorpe’s roommate at the 1912 Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Does My Grandson Think I Should Pay Him for Missing Our Family Vacation?
description: A reader is stunned by a grandson’s request for the cash value of a trip he’s unable to attend.
content: I am treating my family to a special vacation in Alaska. My grandson, 28, and his wife are unable to join us; they are expecting a baby soon. I’m sorry they can’t come, but I was shocked when my grandson asked me for a cash gift equal to what I would have spent for them to join us on the trip. He suggested I donate the money to the baby’s college fund. I am stunned! I was happy to help them with wedding expenses and part of the down payment on their first home. But I told him this is not how life works. Was I wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Slowing Inflation Gives Biden Respite, but High Prices Remain a Problem
description: Speaking at the White House, the president declared that his “economic plan is working.”
content: Signs that inflation eased in July offered a political reprieve for President Biden, who has spent months on the defensive as prices climbed to 40-year highs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: London Children Offered Polio Vaccine Booster as More Virus Is Found in Sewage
description: Children of ages 1 to 9 in the city will be offered a booster after signs that the virus was turning up more frequently in samples. No cases have so far been reported.
content: LONDON — Every child in London age 1 to 9 should be offered a booster dose of polio vaccine, the British health authorities said on Wednesday, after traces of the virus turned up in sewage samples across a quarter of the city’s boroughs, though no individual cases of the disease have been reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Ben Protess and William K. Rashbaum
title: Trump Invokes Fifth Amendment, Attacking Legal System as Troubles Mount
description: The former president declined to answer questions from the office of the New York State attorney general, Letitia James, who leads one of a number of inquiries swirling around him.
content: Donald J. Trump has long derided public figures who invoke their constitutional right against self incrimination, but on Wednesday he took full advantage of the Fifth Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Dana Rubinstein and Michael Rothfeld
title: Under an Unusual Arrangement, Adams’s Confidant Gets City and Casino Salaries
description: Timothy Pearson, a close friend of Mayor Eric Adams, works both as a senior adviser to the mayor and as a vice president overseeing security at the Resorts World New York City casino in Queens.
content: Mayor Eric Adams has appointed a former New York City police official and close confidant as a paid senior adviser — while allowing him to keep his job as an executive at the Resorts World New York City casino in Queens, according to city officials and a person close to Resorts World.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: The Boy Bosses of Silicon Valley Are on Their Way Out
description: They rode their unicorns to fame and fortune. In a rocky market, it got a little less fun.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The young kings of Silicon Valley are dismounting their unicorns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: How the War Changed a Kyiv Museum’s View of Its Past
description: Rather than try to illustrate the war directly, Ukrainian curators turned to older art that inspired new emotions.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Most of the galleries are now empty at the Mystetskyi Arsenal, one of Europe’s largest art museums. As at almost every cultural institution in the Ukrainian capital, its curators and archivists brought down the displays when war broke out on Feb. 24. Much of the collection of about 4,500 objects has been moved to a secure location. Gallery after gallery sits in darkness. And yet: this summer, the Mystetskyi Arsenal is open to the public, with a forceful and beautiful exhibition that’s all the more impressive for its modesty and frank emotions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oleksandr Chubko and Carlotta Gall
title: Months after Russian soldiers withdrew, Bucha begins to bury its unidentified dead.
description: BUCHA, Ukraine — The city of Bucha has begun burying the unidentified victims of the Russian occupation, despite months of research aimed at identifying the dead, reuniting them with family and giving them proper burials.
content: BUCHA, Ukraine — The city of Bucha has begun burying the unidentified victims of the Russian occupation, despite months of research aimed at identifying the dead, reuniting them with family and giving them proper burials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Politics of Persecution
description: For Trump, appearing persecuted is both a security blanket and a weapon.
content: After the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Fla., on Monday — an extraordinary event in the history of the United States — the former president and his allies immediately began to howl that Trump was being persecuted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: These Groups Want Disruptive Climate Protests. Oil Heirs Are Funding Them.
description: Beneficiaries of two American oil fortunes are supporting groups trying to block fossil fuel projects. One donor said he felt a “moral obligation.”
content: They’ve taken hammers to gas pumps and glued themselves to museum masterpieces and busy roadways. They’ve chained themselves to banks, rushed onto a GrandPrix racetrack and tethered themselves to goal posts as tens of thousands of British soccer fans jeered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Review: Finding a Collective Groove in Church and in House Dance
description: In “Lifted: A Gospel House Musical,” the choreographer Rennie Harris tells a tale of redemption and healing loosely inspired by “Oliver Twist.”
content: “In the beginning, God had a groove. And from that groove came the groove of all grooves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Your Blue State Won’t Save You: Why State Politics Is National Politics
description: Zack Beauchamp and Nicole Hemmer on why state-level politics is more important than ever.
content: Last week, Kansans voted in overwhelming numbers to protect abortion rights in their State Constitution — the first instance since the overruling of Roe v. Wade in which voters have been able to weigh in on the issue directly. But local battles aren’t just limited to abortion. There’s guns. There’s school curriculums. Most crucially, there’s voting rights. As national politics becomes increasingly polarized, how we live is going to be decided by local legislation. It’s time we step into the state houses and see what’s happening there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: ‘We Couldn’t Do Anything’: Family Drowns in Seoul Basement During Floods
description: Hundreds of thousands of poor people live in semi-underground homes around the city. The death of a family of three showed ​how vulnerable they are to flooding.
content: SEOUL — At 4:40 p.m. on Monday, the 13-year-old girl texted her ​72-year-old ​grandmother ​who was ​in the hospital, wishing her well and saying that she was praying for her quick recovery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: Elon Musk sells nearly $7 billion in Tesla shares to finance his Twitter deal.
description: The billionaire entrepreneur said he wanted “to avoid an emergency sale of Tesla stock” if he was forced to complete the buyout of the social media company.
content: Elon Musk, the chief executive of the electric vehicle maker Tesla, has sold about $7 billion worth of the company’s stock, a move he said on Twitter was an effort to raise cash in case he was forced to complete his $44 billion deal to acquire Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz, Alan Yuhas and Christiaan Triebert
title: Contradicting Kremlin’s Account, Crimean Officials Detail Explosions’ Extent
description: Blasts at an air base in the Russian-occupied territory damaged 62 apartment buildings and forced hundreds into shelters. Satellite imagery showed destroyed fighter jets.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — After explosions tore through a Russian air base in Crimea on Tuesday, Russia’s Defense Ministry quickly played down the extent of the damage, saying a munitions blast had left no casualties and that no equipment had been destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: What Today’s Inflation Report Means for the Federal Reserve
description: Fed officials are waiting for an inflation slowdown, and economists have predicted that this could signal the start of a deceleration.
content: Consumer Price Index inflation cooled meaningfully in July as gas prices declined, which is good news for the Federal Reserve, though not yet enough for policymakers to conclude that America is through the worst of its burst of rapid price increases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Change These Default Settings and Be Happier With Your Tech
description: Simple steps can make your smartphone, computer and TV work better for you.
content: Many default settings buried deep inside our technology make us share superfluous amounts of data with tech companies. In my last column, I went over how to shut those off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Luke Broadwater and Katie Benner
title: Seizure of Congressman’s Phone Is Latest Sign of Escalating Election Inquiry
description: Representative Scott Perry’s lawyer said he was told he is not a target of the Justice Department’s expanding inquiry into one element of the effort to keep Donald J. Trump in power after his loss in 2020.
content: The F.B.I.’s seizure of Representative Scott Perry’s phone this week was at least the third major action in recent months taken in connection with an escalating federal investigation into efforts by several close allies of former President Donald J. Trump to overturn the 2020 election, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Snyder and Ivan Salinero
title: In Lima, a Home and Studio That Remains a Work in Progress
description: Amid the grayness of Peru’s capital, a multidisciplinary artist creates a place that illuminates both his practice and the city that informs it.
content: WHEN THE LIMA, Peru-based artist Miguel Andrade Valdez started sketching designs for a home and studio in the bohemian district of Barranco, his primary obsession was not the building’s form but how it might give shape to his native city’s stark, paralyzing light. Throughout its austral winter, banks of fog shroud the escarpment that separates the Peruvian capital from the Pacific, turning the sky into a blank, dimensionless field: “Six in the morning looks just like 6 in the evening — there’s nothing to mark the horizon,” says Andrade, 43. Herman Melville, who docked in the city as a 19th-century seaman, devotes a paragraph of “Moby-Dick” (1851) to Lima’s “white veil,” which, he writes, “spreads over her broken ramparts the rigid pallor of an apoplexy that fixes its own distortions.” Many of the city’s 10 million residents call it Lima la Gris — Lima the Gray — others, simply, La Horrible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Ukraine’s ‘Mosquito’ Air Force
description: Most of its drones are off-the-shelf units modified to carry explosives.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Steve Jobs Chose This Designer’s Turtlenecks
description: The real beginning of the fashion-technology love affair and its legacy lies with Issey Miyake, who died last week.
content: Little wonder, really, that Issey Miyake was Steve Jobs’s favorite designer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman
title: Families of Israelis Killed at Munich Olympics Plan Anniversary Boycott
description: The families of the athletes killed by the Black September terrorist group say that the compensation they have been offered is inadequate and will stay away from a ceremony in Munich in September.
content: TEL AVIV — The families of the 11 Israeli athletes who were killed by Palestinian militants at the 1972 Munich Olympics said Wednesday that they intend to boycott a memorial ceremony planned in Germany in September to mark the 50th anniversary of the attack because of a dispute with German authorities over compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Ben Dooley
title: U.S. Insists It Will Operate Around Taiwan, Despite China’s Pressure
description: The confrontation threatens to overwhelm President Biden’s efforts to find a series of issues in which the United States and China can work together.
content: The Biden administration is vowing to continue sailing warships through the Taiwan Strait and to conduct air operations in the region in response to Chinese military drills that U.S. officials say are evolving into a long-term strategy of heightened military pressure on the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Falling Tree Kills 2 Soldiers During Storm in Georgia
description: Three others service members were treated by Army medics and taken to a hospital.
content: Two U.S. Army soldiers were struck by a falling tree and killed on Tuesday while sheltering near Yonah Mountain in northern Georgia, where they had been training before a severe thunderstorm blasted the area with strong winds, Army officials said. Three other service members were injured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: ‘Dangerous Road. No Cell Service. Drive at Own Risk.’
description: Elizabeth Hand’s “Hokuloa Road” brims with menace: vine-choked cliff-top highways, aviaries filled with strange birds, tanks of poisonous sea urchins.
content: Gillian McAllister’s tense new book begins as a woman waits for her beloved teenage son to come home late one night. But then she sees something inexplicable: the boy, Todd, running toward a stranger on the darkened suburban street — and stabbing him to death. “I had to,” he says cryptically as he is led away in handcuffs. “There was no choice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Shafer
title: Meet Mandela Barnes, the 35-Year-Old Candidate Working to Oust Ron Johnson
description: Wisconsin’s lieutenant governor embodies both the flaws and the promise of his generation.
content: MILWAUKEE — Millennials came of age at a time of crisis. They are the first generation in American history positioned to be worse off than their parents, their economic trajectory forever altered by the economic meltdown of the late 2000s, as the ladders to the middle class were pulled up or broken by the crushing burden of student debt, the decline of unions and skyrocketing health care and housing costs, and as rapid technological changes proved more calamitous than democratizing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Vimal Patel
title: Anne Heche Remains in Critical Condition After Car Crash
description: Ms. Heche, 53, was injured on Friday when the car she was in crashed into a two-story home in Los Angeles, causing severe damage and a fire, the authorities said.
content: The actress Anne Heche remained in a coma, in critical condition and on a ventilator on Wednesday, five days after a car she was in crashed into a home in Los Angeles, a representative said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: 92NY’s New Season Includes Ian McEwan and Tom Stoppard
description: The fall season also features Ralph Fiennes, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Katie Couric and Ken Burns.
content: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Katie Couric and Ralph Fiennes are among the array of actors, authors and dancers who will feature in the 92nd Street Y, New York's upcoming fall season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A Normal Back-to-School?
description: This year things are looking more pre-pandemic anytime during the last two years.
content: It’s back-to-school time across the country, and this year, things look, well, normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent Staples
title: When America Joined the Cult of the Confederacy
description: By renaming military bases, the Defense Department dismantles an enduring legacy of the Lost Cause.
content: President Woodrow Wilson transformed government into an engine of white supremacy when he took office in 1913. His administration segregated a federal work force that had been integrated for 50 years and imposed separate white and “colored” bathrooms in federal buildings. As the historian Eric S. Yellin shows in his iconic book “Racism in the Nation’s Service,” segregation was just a prelude. The goal was to drive African Americans from influential jobs and confine them to a “controlled and exploitable class of laborers.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Trump Claims He’s a Victim of Tactics He Once Deployed
description: Donald J. Trump’s efforts to politicize the law enforcement system have now become his shield as he tries to deflect accusations of wrongdoing.
content: WASHINGTON — Two days after the 2020 election that Donald J. Trump refused to admit he lost, his oldest son, Donald Trump Jr., made an urgent recommendation: “Fire Wray.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: A Philly Basketball Reunion Draws N.B.A. Stars Back Home
description: The Danny Rumph Classic in Philadelphia each summer attracts N.B.A. players with local roots and raises awareness about cardiac health, in honor of the tournament’s namesake.
content: PHILADELPHIA — Merge the raucous atmosphere of the Danny Rumph Classic with the risk of injury in competitive summer basketball, and it seems like a risk not worth the reward for the N.B.A. stars playing alongside amateurs and lower-level pros.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Gary Schroen, Who Led the C.I.A. Into Afghanistan, Dies at 80
description: Weeks before the troops arrived, he took a small team into the country to prepare for an invasion and begin the hunt for Osama bin Laden.
content: Gary C. Schroen, a veteran C.I.A. operative who, just weeks after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, led the first team of agents into Afghanistan to prepare for an invasion and begin the hunt for Osama bin Laden and his top lieutenants, died at his home in Alexandria, Va., on Aug. 1, one day after an American missile killed one of the last of those men, Ayman al-Zawahri. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Gas Prices Have Fallen 57 Straight Days
description: The decline in the cost of filling up at the pump has been a big factor in easing inflation.
content: Gasoline prices in the United States have fallen for 57 consecutive days since reaching a high of more than $5 a gallon in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
title: From the Workshop to the War: Creative Use of Drones Lifts Ukraine
description: While Russia lacks an effective long-range strike drone, Ukraine’s experimentation has produced an array of inexpensive, plastic aircraft, jury-rigged to drop grenades or other munitions.
content: POKROVSKE, Ukraine — A private in the Ukrainian army unfolded the rotors of a common hobby drone and, with practiced calm, attached a grenade to a device that can drop objects and was designed for commercial drone deliveries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Presses Congo Leaders to Slow Oil-and-Gas Push in Rainforests
description: The secretary of state’s efforts led to the U.S. and the Democratic Republic of Congo agreeing to have a team look at environmental conservation.
content: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Pushing for a reconsideration of plans by the Democratic Republic of Congo to auction parts of its vast rainforests and peatlands, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken announced that American and Congolese officials would form a team to examine proposed oil-and-gas extraction in those areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Arizonans Trusted Kari Lake to Tell It Straight on TV. Will They Trust Her as Governor?
description: The former news anchor is running on falsehoods about the 2020 election. She is undeterred about her chances in November: ‘I am beloved by people.’
content: PHOENIX — Kari Lake worked her way through television interviews at her election night party, fielding a barrage of questions about her bid to be Arizona’s next governor. Votes were still being counted, and she’d been up all night. But Ms. Lake, a first-time candidate, didn’t flinch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Russia’s grip on Ukrainian cyberspace.
content: In parts of Russian-occupied Ukraine, Russia has also begun occupying cyberspace. It has cleaved off Ukrainians in Kherson, Melitopol and Mariupol from the rest of the country, limiting access to news about the war and communication with loved ones. In some territories, the internet and cellular networks have been shut down altogether.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden Signs Bill to Help Veterans Who Were Exposed to Toxic Burn Pits
description: President Biden, who has long advocated the expanded benefits, has speculated that his son Beau developed brain cancer because of exposure to burn pits when he served in Iraq.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Wednesday signed into law a bill that expands medical benefits for veterans who were exposed to toxins from burning pits of trash on military bases, ending a yearslong quest for support by veterans and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Tamisiea
title: Modern and Ancient Crickets May Sing the Same Song
description: With a one-of-a-kind museum specimen, researchers recreated the chirp of ancient cricket relatives that droned alongside the dinosaurs.
content: Whether it’s a cicada’s earsplitting drone, a bee’s blaring buzz or a cricket’s incessant chirp, insects are a staple of summer’s score. And arthropods have been making a racket for hundreds of millions of years. One of the noisier groups has been the Prophalangopsidae, a suite of singing insects that went mainstream during the Jurassic period when some 100 species clamored about. While related to modern crickets and katydids, these ancient arthropods left few direct descendants, making it difficult to decipher what these Mesozoic maestros sounded like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Mets Make Their Case as New York’s Best Team
description: A run of 15 wins in 17 games has catapulted the Mets past the Yankees. With the second-best record in the majors and a big division lead, things are looking good.
content: With talk earlier this year about this possibly being the best New York baseball season ever, it had seemed clear that there was at least a small divide between the city’s major league teams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Kids’ Mental Health Is a ‘National Emergency.’ Therapists Are in Short Supply.
description: Could books and online materials help fill the gap?
content: At the beginning of the year, I started hearing from readers across the country that there were long waiting lists for child and adolescent mental health providers. Many of their kids were really struggling, often with anxiety and depression. When these parents tried to find help, they found there was, in some cases, up to a six-month wait to even get in the door at a therapist’s office for an assessment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: The Art of Making Garden Rooms
description: Want to create outdoor rooms in your garden? At Sakonnet, a magical landscape in coastal Rhode Island, you can learn from the masters.
content: It’s the key question in making any garden: How do you get all the plants you can’t resist and the ideas insistently flooding your imagination to coalesce on common ground?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $575,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Louisiana and Georgia
description: An eight-bedroom Edwardian house in Springfield, a 1913 home in New Orleans and a three-bedroom bungalow in Atlanta.
content: This house is in the Forest Park Heights Historic District, added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982. It was designed by G. Wood Taylor, the architect of a number of grand estates in the area, for Frank L. Brigham, the president of a clothing company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Carly Olson
title: ‘If you’re innocent, why are you taking the Fifth Amendment?’ Trump’s position on declining to testify has changed over time.
description: Over the years, the former president has generally criticized other politicians for taking the Fifth Amendment. But on Wednesday, he invoked the right himself.
content: Over the years, former President Donald J. Trump has generally criticized other politicians for taking the Fifth Amendment. But on Wednesday, he invoked the right himself during a deposition at the office of the New York attorney general, and it wasn’t the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Get It? Got It!
description: Karen Lurie’s puzzle is a bit pedantic.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations and a welcome back to the constructor Karen Lurie, who is making her second appearance in the New York Times Crossword, following up on her hilarious SPOILER ALERT puzzle from earlier this year. Between that puzzle and this one, Ms. Lurie has firmly established herself as a constructor who makes funny puzzles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Lycra Legacy of Olivia Newton-John’s ‘Physical’
description: Athleisure, leggings, shapewear owe a debt of gratitude to the iconic video.
content: A funny thing happened when Kameron Lennox revisited the music video for “Physical,” the 1981 pop megahit by Olivia Newton-John, who died on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Prentiss, 15 and Feeling Deeply
description: The dream-pop singer and songwriter from Jackson, Miss., tries out a range of sounds and speaks from the heart on his upcoming debut album, “Crescent.”
content: In his music videos, several of which have lately become tastemaker manna, Prentiss looks more like a kid brother than a rock-star rebel. Many show him out in nature wearing hippie-ish hand-me-downs and singing sweetly heartbroken lyrics that sometimes come from poems he writes on his phone. “I try not to overthink it,” he said on a recent video call from his Jackson, Miss., home just after his daily workout, his hair a bounteous bushel of curls. “My purest emotion comes from my first thought.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Tim Michels, with Trump’s backing, is Wisconsin Republicans’ choice for governor.
description: He has contemplated trying to overturn the 2020 election, a legal impossibility that is a popular cause among Wisconsin Republicans.
content: KAUKAUNA, Wis. — Tim Michels, a millionaire construction magnate endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, won Wisconsin’s Republican primary for governor, according to The Associated Press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: How a New Class of Republicans Could Push America to the Right
description: Beyond elections and voting issues, these Trump-aligned candidates could shape the country’s policies on abortion, climate change, same-sex marriage and much more.
content: Much of the attention paid to Donald Trump’s favorite candidates running in the midterms has focused — rightly! — on their support for relitigating the 2020 election. (Which, for those still unsure, was not stolen.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: A tally of damage near a Crimean air base contradicts the Kremlin’s assertions.
description: ODESA, Ukraine — Damage from a series of explosions at a Russian air base in Crimea appeared to be greater than the Kremlin has described, as officials on the Russia-occupied peninsula on Wednesday declared a state of emergency and said that dozens of nearby homes and commercial structures had been hit.
content: ODESA, Ukraine — Damage from a series of explosions at a Russian air base in Crimea appeared to be greater than the Kremlin has described, as officials on the Russia-occupied peninsula on Wednesday declared a state of emergency and said that dozens of nearby homes and commercial structures had been hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Sentence of American Lawyer Held in U.A.E. Is Overturned
description: The man, Asim Ghafoor — who was convicted in absentia of financial crimes and had once worked with Jamal Khashoggi — is expected to be released.
content: CAIRO — An American lawyer imprisoned in the United Arab Emirates since mid-July is expected to be released after his sentence was overturned by an Emirati court, reversing a punishment that raised alarm that he was being targeted for political reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Displaced by War, Ukrainians Open a New Front as Entrepreneurs
description: Ukrainians forced from their hometowns by Russia’s invasion find some solace, and success, setting up shop in a new city.
content: Oksana Dudyk scanned a small selection of ornamental plants lining the shelves of her new florist shop, recently opened in this city on Ukraine’s western frontier. Her eye landed on the perfect bloom for a new customer: fuchsia-colored primroses, vivid and lush, ideal for brightening an austere corner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: House Hunting in South Africa: Carved Into a Mountain in Cape Town
description: On the Western Cape, South Africa’s most active market, sales are booming, driven largely by European buyers seeking safe investments.
content: This five-bedroom home backs onto the slopes of Table Mountain in Oranjezicht, a suburb of Cape Town, South Africa. Set on about three quarters of an acre, the home is designed to mimic the landscape of the mountain, a prominent landmark, with a wavy concrete roof and ample use of wood and stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: How We Think About Politics Changes What We Think About Politics
description: We are pulling apart from each other, and it’s making our problems worse.
content: When so many voters — a majority, in fact — say that they prefer consensus to conflict, why does polarization continue to intensify?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jan Hoffman
title: The Author of ‘Dopesick’ Returns to Familiar Ground
description: In “Raising Lazarus,” Beth Macy considers how — or whether — we will ever be able to put the overdose epidemic behind us.
content: “Dopesick,” Beth Macy’s deeply reported account of how opioids came to savage so many Appalachian families, concludes with a wrenching image of Patricia Mehrmann tenderly preparing her 28-year-old daughter, Tess Henry, for burial. Tess is a major figure in the book, with Macy detailing how, for nearly two years, the author herself would even ferry Tess to rehab support groups, hold her infant during sessions and visit her in psych wards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Stacey Abrams temporarily steps off the campaign trail after contracting the coronavirus.
description: She said she planned to hold meetings by Zoom and phone while isolating at home for “the next few days,” and added that she had tested negative before delivering a speech Tuesday evening in Atlanta.
content: Stacey Abrams, the Democratic nominee for governor of Georgia, tested positive for the coronavirus on Wednesday, taking her off the campaign trail temporarily in her race against Gov. Brian Kemp.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 10, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Aug. 10, 2022.
content: A profile on Saturday about Mechai Viravaidya, known as “Captain Condom” for his campaigns to promote safe sex and family planning, misstated the average number of children a Thai family had in the early 1970s. It was five, not seven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Jones
title: Sneeze by Sneeze, Sponges Fill the Seas With Their Mucus
description: You might be tempted to say “gesundheit,” but the sea creature’s snot helps feed other marine organisms.
content: Sneezing is far from a uniquely human behavior. Maybe you’ve seen your dog or cat do it, or watched a YouTube video of a giraffe sneezing on an unsuspecting toddler at the zoo. In fact, sneezing doesn’t even require a nervous system, let alone a nose, and dates back to some of the first multicellular animals: sponges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Sheera Frenkel
title: Russian propaganda is spreading in Spanish and Arabic and in places outside the West.
description: When Russia’s war in Ukraine began, Facebook, Twitter and other social media giants moved to block or limit the reach of the accounts of the Kremlin’s propaganda machine in the West. The effort, though, has been limited by geography and language, creating a patchwork of restrictions rather than a blanket ban.
content: When Russia’s war in Ukraine began, Facebook, Twitter and other social media giants moved to block or limit the reach of the accounts of the Kremlin’s propaganda machine in the West. The effort, though, has been limited by geography and language, creating a patchwork of restrictions rather than a blanket ban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Rosenbloom
title: Tracking Ships (and Sharks) and Tying Knots: Apps to Enrich Your Seaside Vacation
description: With the right software on your phone you can turn a getaway on the water into an opportunity for discovery, from deciphering signal flags to forecasting tides.
content: Of all summer’s pleasures, few are as irresistible as a getaway by the water, be it an ocean, lake or city harbor. You can swim, sail, fish and partake of the age-old tradition of lazing around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Humans Know a Lot, This Author Concedes, and Most of It Is Useless
description: The book “If Nietzsche Were a Narwhal,” by Justin Gregg, contrasts human thought with animal intelligence. The people come up short.
content: “Human, all too human”: It’s a thought that occurred to me a few times while reading Justin Gregg’s “If Nietzsche Were a Narwhal,” and not just because the phrase also happens to be the title of a work by Nietzsche himself. Gregg’s clever and provocative book is full of irreverent notions and funny anecdotes — the creative upside to being a human animal. But our ability to abstract from our immediate experience means we can take that creativity too far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Trump Declines to Answer Questions
description: Plus new details about explosions in Crimea and revelations about the victims of Seoul’s floods.
content: Donald Trump declined to answer questions in a civil inquiry into his company’s business practices yesterday, invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: The Seagram Building’s New Playground
description: The famous midtown property, an official city landmark, is opening a new sports and leisure lounge.
content: The famous midtown property, an official city landmark, is opening a new sports and leisure lounge.

description: This modern five-bedroom home, which backs onto the slopes of Table Mountain in the suburbs of Cape Town, South Africa, is for sale for $4.7 million.

description: Want to create outdoor rooms in your garden? At Sakonnet, in coastal Rhode Island, you can learn from the masters.

title: Living In ... Peekskill, N.Y.
description: Newcomers praise this diverse Westchester city for its galleries, art studios and welcoming vibe: ‘It’s easy to be part of the community.’

author: By Associated Press
title: Tim Michels Is Wisconsin Republicans’ Choice for Governor
description: Tim Michels, a Wisconsin native who inherited an infrastructure company from his father and was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, won Wisconsin’s Republican primary for governor.
content: Tim Michels, a Wisconsin native who inherited an infrastructure company from his father and was endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump, won Wisconsin’s Republican primary for governor.

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Signs Bill to Help Veterans Exposed to Toxins
description: President Biden signed a bill into law that expands medical benefits for veterans who were exposed to toxins from burn pits on military bases.
content: President Biden signed a bill into law that expands medical benefits for veterans who were exposed to toxins from burn pits on military bases.
